Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A package arrives slightly later than expected, but still within the same day
Story: I was just about to leave for my next delivery when my phone buzzed with a message from Mom: “Can you call? Dad’s not feeling well.” As a son, I knew what was expected of me. I should check in, ask if everything’s okay, offer comfort, maybe even head home if they needed me. But as a delivery person, I was already running behind. The last package had arrived late at the depot, and my supervisor had reminded me—again—how important it was to deliver every parcel on time. The address was only a few blocks away, but if I stopped to call my parents, I’d risk being late and possibly getting a complaint. My parents counted on me for emotional support, especially when things felt uncertain at home. My job, though, demanded punctuality and reliability. I stood there, phone in hand, heart pounding, torn between the urge to call home and the pressure to get back on the road.
